This is a long review so if you want just a brief summary of why I recommend Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior skip to Results and read from there.RuneStorm brings to life all of our dreams by finally making a title where you get to see what happens after you play a game. After playing Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior you’ll learn that maybe you should reconsider before you go out of your way to break everything in a room.Story:Lo Wang got in a devastating battle at a temple nearby destroying everything in sight. You are hired as a janitor to clean up a terrible mess. Bodies are everywhere, art is destroyed, and you’re the only man for the job. Campaign:There is one level; it’s the same as the first level in the new Shadow Warrior game. It’s your job to clean it up with a mop and your hands. You must deposit the debris into various incinerators, mop up blood, and grab all the cash you can find. The campaign only has two achievements, clean up everything and grab all the money. If you can do this you’ve proven that “you’re the best around and nothing’s ever gonna to keep you down.”Gameplay:This game plays similar to an FPS. The camera is always in first person and your two weapons are a mop and your hands. You must pick up garbage with your hands and throw it into incinerators while mopping up gallons of blood. You better keep your mop clean, but beware for some odd reason the machines that provide water can shoot out an organ. Similar to a normal janitor after you are done you must clock out.Results:If you have always wondered what happens after a game, wonder what life as a janitor for crime scenes would be like, or even just want to play a game that doesn’t push your wits then Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is for you. This brilliant game is hilarious to play if you just beat the first level of Shadow Warrior. For some odd reason the character sounds exactly like Lo Wang, which makes me wonder if after he saved the universe he decided to give up fighting and clean up his messes. Pros:+You get to experience Shadow Warrior through a whole new light.+You get to clean up bodies, mop up blood, and steal money… how many games offer that?+Good graphics+Easy gameplay, with simple controls.+Funny dialogue+Two straightforward achievements+Its free if you already own Shadow Warrior (2013)+YOU GET TO BE A JANITORCons:-Cleaning up everything achievement can be really annoying as a single bullet shell could be the culprit.-There is only one level (why can’t we clean more)

												Well - as you probably know from other reviews, Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a free gift for users who purchase Shadow Warrior, so in this case we can't talk about price-value ratio.This leaves us with enjoyment-time ratio - it was free, but does it worth the time to play?The game is really simple: clean up the temple. You have your trustworthy mop (press 1) your hands, trained on numerous temples you cleaned before (press 2) and "The Sniffer" (press 3) which can detect blood and clutter around you (left click to turn on/off, right click to change mode)The game mechanically both simple and great. You need to clean the place up - get shurikens, katanas, guns and smashed statues to the incinerator, as well as mop up the blood and clean up the severed torsos, limbs, internal organs (Hey, they had a wild party previously!) The little trick is in the later items - bumping into objects, kicking body parts will splatter blood around, and if you step into a blood puddle, you'll leave nice bloodie footprints for a while. You don't need to take every single item to the incinerator - there are yellow crates in which you can dump items, then bring them in one turn. Basically this is the most intresting part of the game.  It's because the game is kinda more physics-simulator than a real game. You can actually throw/put items into the crates, and you can shake them out of it. Tip it over. Collide with a wall and drop it.The game's physics great, and actually somehow the theme also fares really well.  I was mainly playing this when I was too sleepy to play with anything that requires thinking, and actually this was quite a good game for that purpose - I finished it in about 3 hours.Sadly I can't tell anything from the multiplayer options, I haven't tried it out yet.I don't know if there is any point of writing this review as currently the game isn't sold separately but at this point I think I summed the game up quite nicely, maybe some of you will find it useful eventually :)I liked the game, it's really like a good old household chores - while you do the cleaning and menial work, you don't really need to pay attention,  you can think about everything you want. 												A fun little bonus for any OCD fans of the new Shadow Warrior game.  Sure, Lo Wang can cut a swath through an army of men, but can he clean up after himself?Like many who have played any of the Viscera Cleanup Detail games, I have to say that this game is surprisingly fun for essentially being a housecleaning simulator.  Yeah, on the one hand it's not an adrenaline rush where you feel like a badass for fighting of armies of dudes left and right.  On the other hand though, it's relaxing and pleasant.  Here is a goal, here are your tools, complete as you will.  No time limit, no rush, no one else mucking it up.This particular iteration gets a little bit of a comedic boost by putting you in the shoes of Lo Wang himself, who is none too shy about voicing his opinions on the entire process.  While none of the lines were laugh out loud material, the commentary still brought a smile to my face, making an already enjoyable experience that much better.There are some flaws with this particular version of Viscera Cleanup Detail though.  For one, there are exactly zero instructions available through the game itself.  No way to see controls, no explanation of the objects in the game, no explanation of how to gather money, dispose of remains, or even how to clean your mop.  Most of the game's mechanics I figured out just by poking around, but quite a few I didn't understand until late in my playthrough, things like disposing of items in the Incinerator or how I could get fresh buckets of water from a machine that literally makes buckets of water.  It made me feel a bit cheated in some ways, and certainly undermined a bit of my enjoyment of the game.There is an argument that could be made for game mechanics not being directly explained, since they are relatively simple and not too difficult to figure out.  However, I can really think of no excuse for why there's no way to display the game's controls, much less any way to rebind them.  I will admit that this is not a title where keybindings can make the difference between success and failure, but at the same time the Unreal engine is hardly a difficult engine to add a keybind menu to.  At the very least having an option to display the keybindings would be trivial, and the fact that there's no option to show them is almost unforgivable.  Really, what were the devs thinking?Now, that said, the instructional issues are not a dealbreaker, not for a relatively low-key game such as this.  I still had a surprisingly good time guiding Lo Wang as he cleaned up his own trail of blood, gore, and dismemberment.  As long as you're comfortable with the bog-standard WASD control setup and are willing to look up instructions elsewhere, Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a fun little diversion worth spending a few hours on.

Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is an interesting exploration into the realities of what would happen after a typical video game murder rampage. Did you ever consider how the mess you made got dealt with? Well, now you will.You are not a soldier, an assassin, a gangster, or any sort of typical hero or villain. You are instead a janitor with a bad work assignment: Clean up the mess Lo Wang left behind in the temple. How did you get that job, and what sort of cleaning company handles these sorts of massacres? No one knows.You are armed with a mop, some gloves, and a janitorial radar and must scrub every inch of the temple and remove all of the body parts and other junk, all while looking out for cash (a fair bonus!). Blood is wiped away with a mop and some water, while everything else can be incinerated. When you have had enough, you punch out and go home.The GoodAn amusing premise that makes you look at your heroic rampage in a new lightFree with Shadow WarriorThe BadQuite monotonousYou will question why you are not spending the time cleaning your own homeThe Bottom LineViscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is an amusing bonus game that takes a fun look at the consequences of a video game bloodbath. It is not for everyone, but with the right sense of humour it can be fun for a short while.

												I was fortunate enough to win the entire Viscera package in a giveaway, and I'm really happy to own this game. I started with Santa's Rampage, then moved on to this one (will be doing the actual Viscera game soon). I have already reviewed Santa's Rampage, and these two games are very similar. The link to SR has been provided above.If you like the Shadow Warrior theme, cleaning, and relaxing, casual gameplay, then you will enjoy this game.Since I have already provided the link to SR, I will be commenting on the differences between the two games (SR and Shadow Warrior).The aesthetics in Shadow Warrior are very, very good. The building you are in is nicely detailed with different museum pieces, and the variety of things to clean up is good. Like SR, there is a radio you can pick up and carry around if you want some music while you play. The music is very good and matches the theme appropriately - the menu screen music is also really nice. I have noticed that your character actually speaks and makes comments during gameplay - usually when you pick up stuff. The level is also fairly larger than SR, but a lot more symmetrical.Thus far, I have found no way to kill yourself, so I do not think this is possible in SW. There are only two achievements - completely cleaning the building and amassing 2 million dollars in your trunk. I was unable to find the last bit of mess to cleanup - I scoured the ENTIRE building with my sniffer and just could not find any blood splatters =(. I also ended with 1,875,000 dollars (so close!). I am unsure whether or not the museum pieces are worth money (I had thrown all of them into the furnace), so that might contribute to the final count when you punch out.The game is still fairly buggy at times - in particular with the ridiculous collision mechanics. Sometimes pieces can just randomly go flying, and I've also noticed that some of the doors will swing around violently. As in SR, the collision mechanics between objects are EXTREMELY sensitive, so consider walking (hold CTRL) whenever you are carrying water buckets and the hazardous waste containers. Overall, this game is very fun, and you should check it out if you are interested in this concept.Definitely recommend!If you like this review, please consider checking out DJSF's Rogue Reviews Steam Group for more in-depth reviews

												I booted this one up right after beating the Shadow Warrior campaign for the first time.  I'm familiar with the full Viscera Cleanup Detail and the Santa's Workshop stand-alone, but had yet to play either of those, so I was going into this experience with fresh eyes.  Boy, what an experience it turned out to be.  I had seen the trailers, the screenshots, but actually walking into Zilla's dojo to pick up the mess left by Lo Wang was somehow, as boring as the idea of janitorial labor may sound, so cathartic and entertaining.  I'm not sure if the assets were reused ad-naseum from Shadow Warrior, but this stand alone still looks as gorgeous as the base game.  The new parts added in specifically for VCD have just a vaguely more cartoonish style to them than the rest of the game, but it isn't jarring, and just makes things easier to play as you can easily, visually, distinguish what is part of the map, and what is a tool to help you clean it.  In my playthrough, I spent HOURS scrubbing the hell out of the floor, the walls, and burning any body part, organ, or piece of shrapnel that didn't belong.  The tasks were reptitive, but not in annoying way, it felt a lot more like playing something that keeps you coming back despite staying the same mechanically, like Tetris, than it did actually doing a chore like mowing the lawn or shoveling the sidewalk.  Despite all of this, the punchout machine still gave me flak for not completing the job properly, for someone with severe OCD this could probably be maddening, as I walked around the map for a good ten minutes looking for anything I had forgotten to clean up.  I guess even in the virtual space, perfection isn't easily obtained.  This nice little freebie (yes,it comes free with the base Shadow Warrior purchase) has me sold on the main Viscera Cleanup Detail game, and I'm looking forward to seeing how RuneStorm expands upon the concept for a full-blown title of their own design.

												Viscera Cleanup Detail is a game you will either love or hate, and this little gem serves as a great introduction to the main game of VCD. You are a janitor; and in this case you clean for the Zilla Corporation, making the temple that serves as the prologue for Flying Wild Hog's Shadow Warrior squeaky clean. For best results, play this after you finish the prologue; then you will either be in awe or upset at the mess you made.Like in the main VCD game, you're a janitor armed with only a mop, a 'sniffer', endless supplies of water buckets and biohazard crates, incinerators, and your own two hands to clean up the messes made by gore and gib happy protagonists like Lo Wang. The cleaning action that you find in the main game is found alive and well here. Even though most of the rooms are red, it is remarkably easy to locate blood and mop it up. Smaller items like tiny gibs and shell casings are kept to a minimum, sure to please longtime players of VCD who routinely come across piles of spent shells. Finally, in a move sure to make this an easy cleanup, you're given two incinerators and two mop bucket generators which will make the job go faster, not to mention that the game generously has spawned a number of buckets and biohazard crates waiting for fresh new janitors to utilize.So while you are cursing Lo Wang for making your life hard, this level adds a few new things to entertain you while you clean. First off, your janitor has a voice who comments on the messes and whistles to himself. He adds some character to the game ("Dammit, they used an automatic!). He lapses into repeats after some time but they never wear out their welcome. A radio in the first hall blasts the soundtrack to Shadow Warrior. Finally, SPOILER FOR SHADOW WARRIOR: remember how in the prologue Lo Wang walks into the hall with two million dollars? A side goal to cleaning up the temple is to collect all of the cash you find and toss it into the janitor's private trunk. It adds some variety to the clean-all-the-things formula that VCD is known for.  END SPOILERThe game is still not without its glitches, and the sniffer for finding missed debris or gibs is still hit or miss, but it's nice to see that the improvements developer RuneStorm have made to the VCD experience has created a fun little companion game to Shadow Warrior. For VCD veterans, it's another level to test their ability to clean.

I just had to clean up everything. It's oddly entertaining for a game that is basically about janitorial duties. There are a few problems like the fact that all buckets, waste baskets and the money basket are a chore to carry around and sometimes get stuck in the floor causing either you or the object your carrying to be propelled along. It's kind of annoying yet somewhat charming. You pick up limbs and giblets of the enemy combatants in the game Shadow Warrior and have to incinerate them by either carrying them into the waste baskets or just throwing them in yourself. Carrying the small items in your hands like the body parts works much better than the baskets so I just took them individually unless I there was small items on the floor like bullets which I would collect in the baskets. The second part of you job is to mop up blood and this can be made hard because sometimes the blood can be very faded. Luckily there is a tracker which both tells you when your near blood and near body parts depending on which mouse button you click to turn it on. I personally like the fact that the tracker is not just a GPS that leads you to the exact location next bloodstain but instead a object that beeps faster the closer you are. Some may find it annoying in a world where games always tell us where to go even for the secrets but like Shadow Warrior, Viscera Cleanup Deatail has a feeling of less hand holding even while in an area that is less open than most games. For achievements there is of course the achievement for cleaning up the whole place and the achievement for getting all the hidden money in the game. There are 20 stacks of cash in the game that are usually in piles of body parts that you must put in a cash box iin order to unlock the achievement. While both of these achievements seem missable they are actually very easy to track. Just go to the door that has the device that asks you if you want to leave and push the button to activate and to leave. It will then tell you how much money you have and whether the rooms are all clear. If it says you have less than 2 million dollars and you left the room unclean than you simply push the button that you actually want to stay. Then just go through the rooms again once with the giblets tracker and then again with the blood tracker to find what you have missed. It's actually a very simple yet oddly entertaining game. For a free add-on to a game that I would say is worth it's price point it is an oddly entertaining experience that I oddly wrote a lot about in this review. You don't need to pick up Shadow Warrior to play this game but I highly suggest it since Shadow Warrior itself is a refreshing and gory FPS that actually has a fun sword mechanic.

												The game comes with Shadow Warrior which is a game that is already worth it's price point with how fun it is but this is one of those games that for some reason held my attention for the whole time I was playing it. I just had to clean up everything. It's oddly entertaining for a game that is basically about janitorial duties. There are a few problems like the fact that all buckets, waste baskets and the money basket are a chore to carry around and sometimes get stuck in the floor causing either you or the object your carrying to be propelled along. It's kind of annoying yet somewhat charming. You pick up limbs and giblets of the enemy combatants in the game Shadow Warrior and have to incinerate them by either carrying them into the waste baskets or just throwing them in yourself. Carrying the small items in your hands like the body parts works much better than the baskets so I just took them individually unless I there was small items on the floor like bullets which I would collect in the baskets. The second part of you job is to mop up blood and this can be made hard because sometimes the blood can be very faded. Luckily there is a tracker which both tells you when your near blood and near body parts depending on which mouse button you click to turn it on. I personally like the fact that the tracker is not just a GPS that leads you to the exact location next bloodstain but instead a object that beeps faster the closer you are. Some may find it annoying in a world where games always tell us where to go even for the secrets but like Shadow Warrior, Viscera Cleanup Deatail has a feeling of less hand holding even while in an area that is less open than most games. For achievements there is of course the achievement for cleaning up the whole place and the achievement for getting all the hidden money in the game. There are 20 stacks of cash in the game that are usually in piles of body parts that you must put in a cash box iin order to unlock the achievement. While both of these achievements seem missable they are actually very easy to track. Just go to the door that has the device that asks you if you want to leave and push the button to activate and to leave. It will then tell you how much money you have and whether the rooms are all clear. If it says you have less than 2 million dollars and you left the room unclean than you simply push the button that you actually want to stay. Then just go through the rooms again once with the giblets tracker and then again with the blood tracker to find what you have missed. It's actually a very simple yet oddly entertaining game. For a free add-on to a game that I would say is worth it's price point it is an oddly entertaining experience that I oddly wrote a lot about in this review. You don't need to pick up Shadow Warrior to play this game but I highly suggest it since Shadow Warrior itself is a refreshing and gory FPS that actually has a fun sword mechanic.

												Viscera Cleanup Detail is a game you will either love or hate, and this little gem serves as a great introduction to the main game of VCD. You are a janitor; and in this case you clean for the Zilla Corporation, making the temple that serves as the prologue for Flying Wild Hog's Shadow Warrior squeaky clean. For best results, play this after you finish the prologue; then you will either be in awe or upset at the mess you made.Like in the main VCD game, you're a janitor armed with only a mop, a 'sniffer', endless supplies of water buckets and biohazard crates, incinerators, and your own two hands to clean up the messes made by gore and gib happy protagonists like Lo Wang. The cleaning action that you find in the main game is found alive and well here. Even though most of the rooms are red, it is remarkably easy to locate blood and mop it up. Smaller items like tiny gibs and shell casings are kept to a minimum, sure to please longtime players of VCD who routinely come across piles of spent shells. Finally, in a move sure to make this an easy cleanup, you're given two incinerators and two mop bucket generators which will make the job go faster, not to mention that the game generously has spawned a number of buckets and biohazard crates waiting for fresh new janitors to utilize.So while you are cursing Lo Wang for making your life hard, this level adds a few new things to entertain you while you clean. First off, your janitor has a voice who comments on the messes and whistles to himself. He adds some character to the game ("Dammit, they used an automatic!). He lapses into repeats after some time but they never wear out their welcome. A radio in the first hall blasts the soundtrack to Shadow Warrior. Finally, SPOILER FOR SHADOW WARRIOR: remember how in the prologue Lo Wang walks into the hall with two million dollars? A side goal to cleaning up the temple is to collect all of the cash you find and toss it into the janitor's private trunk. It adds some variety to the clean-all-the-things formula that VCD is known for.  END SPOILERThe game is still not without its glitches, and the sniffer for finding missed debris or gibs is still hit or miss, but it's nice to see that the improvements developer RuneStorm have made to the VCD experience has created a fun little companion game to Shadow Warrior. For VCD veterans, it's another level to test their ability to clean.

Swords, guns, ninja stars and punchy one-linersViscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a 1 hour level themed about the newer Shadow Warrior game released in 2013. Though I never played Shadow Warrior I say others play it and it’s your typical Hack and Slash shoot em' up type of deal with lots of one-liners, loads of guys with swords, guns and excessive amounts of blood. How is this relevant to this game you might be wondering? Well it was produced as a Pre-Order Bonus for buying Shadow Warrior back when it released then given to Viscera Cleanup Detail buyers as well which as a fan of the game I great for us to get a little more content out of the game like they did with Santa's Rampage. Only this time there is only 2 achievements, both of which are very easy to get and leaves you with the rewarding 100% completion if you've completed the level and collected all the cash. The level itself is pretty simple, 2 large rooms with small connecting corridors connecting them as well as stairs to the upper part of each room which only have a little to clean up. Majority of the mess is in the large room and they provide you with 2 furnaces, 1 in each room so you don't have to keep running back which is nice!The cleaner takes the role as if he is connected to the Shadow Warrior game with one-liners such as "Hey, I know this guy... Who's laughing now!" when you pick up a head or "I hope these gloves are thick enough" when you pick up glass shards etc. This makes the level really stand out from the others and adds a little fun to the mix. He does whistle every now and then which get annoying because of the high pitch but its fine. 8/10Enjoyable 1 hour map, funny dialogue and easy 100% achievements

												While it may be considered cheating, this is actually by far the easiest 100% achievements of any game on Steam. All of the cash was acquired with 5-10 minutes using screenshots, and then the mess was all cleaned up within 30 seconds using console commands. 10/10 would walk around for 10 minutes, type two lines into the console and scroll up and down on my mouse for a few seconds again.Seriously though, it's a chill way to pass the time if you just want to relax and do something relatively tedious for an hour. 100% accuracy should really only be the goal for the achievements though. The game doesn't stay fun for long enough in one go to really aim for a complete clean every go-around. All in all, it's an interesting concept, and I can't really give it a thumbs down, because it's free with a game that I also would recommend. Worst case scenario, Shadow Warrior is really fun, so buy that game and give this a once over to boost your overall profile percentage by a point.

												Viscera Cleanup Detail: Shadow Warrior is a stand-alone one-level spin-off of a VCD game. In that game you play as Janitor who has to clean up mess after alien movies massacres. Casual fun and jokish simulator, but amusing. This one came out before main game was even finished in 2013 as free offer to owners of Shadow Warrior. They say that they will merge this one into main game soon.Oh, and it kinda has multiplayer too.So, to enjoy the game to the fullest, first you should load up Shadow Warrior and start up new game. Maybe even pick the highest difficulty. Then get into the first fight and take your sweet time slashing people with katana and throwing shurikens randomly at things. Enjoy the blood and massacre. Then once you beat the chapter 0, close the game and load this one up.Bloody hell, Lo Wang! Just look at all the mess that my alter-ego left!(No, don't want to say that VCD:SW copies massacre from main game, albeit it would have been awesome)Then classic gameplay of VCD goes on, cleaning stuff and then running around with beeper to find that last patch of blood that you would in the end fail to see and you will just mop up the spot around.It shows that this one is the earliest VCD on Steam. Unlike Santa's Workshop, there is almost nothing that can go wrong, no dynamite, no way to kill yourself. Some surface, mostly ceiling, thankfully are mess-proof, otherwise you would have never reached blood on the roof. So you can just move on and slowly clean it up for giggles after main game. Hm, main hero alo throws one-liners, not something I seen in other VCDs. They sound quite familar, albeit get old.Quite amusing. All yay for this free offer.
